article.title: Release Notes
article.subtitle: EdEdubuntu &distro-rev; "&distro-version;"
article.para: Edubuntu is a Linux distribution for your desktop or server, with a fast and easy install, regular releases, a tight selection of excellent applications installed by default, and every other software you can imagine available from the Internet. Edubuntu provides security updates for 18 months after each release, and professional technical support is available from many companies around the world.

These Release Notes cover new features in Edubuntu &distro-rev;, download and installation notes, known issues, and frequently asked questions. Please read these notes before, during, and after installation and configuration of Edubuntu &distro-rev; before reporting bugs in Launchpad.

sect1.title: What's New
sect1.para: Edubuntu is released regulary and predictably. Since our October 2005 debut release (Edubuntu 5.10), we've made a lot of improvements to give you the best educational environment with free software, the biggest of which is that Edubuntu &distro-rev; is now available on the PowerPC platform! Much of what Ubuntu offers is also available to Edubuntu with some additional software:

listitem.para: A set of selected educational apps containing:
most of the kdeedu suite
Gcompris
Scribus desktop publishing
Blender 3D Modeller
Dia Diagram Editor
Kino Video Editor
and lots more!
Fresh, colorful artwork for the desktop with support for three themes for three age groups
Full LTSP client functionality by default
New documentation (Edubuntu &distro-rev; Quick Guide and Edubuntu &distro-rev; Cookbook)
Standalone Classroom server installed by default, based on the brand-new Ubuntu thin-client infrastructure developed in cooperation with the LTSP project
Simple NFS root setup with automatic hardware detection through initramfs-tools
Support for up to 4 gigabytes of RAM by default on 32-bit architectures
Kernel support for cluster filesystems (OCFS2 and GFS)
Linux &linux-kernel-version; with many updated drivers from third parties
HP all-in-one printer/scanner devices are supported out of the box
Bluetooth input devices (such as keyboards and mice) are supported out of the box
Multiple audio devices are handled more gracefully (and one can easily select the default device)
Automated installation of the thin-client environment by default
Easy installation of the ltsp server by default with as few questions as possible
Optional workstation install for standalone workstations (just type workstation at the CD boot prompt)

sect2.para: As always, Edubuntu includes the very best of the 100% free/libre application software world, and each new release incorporates countless new features and bugfixes from the global development community.

sect2.title: System Requirements
sect2.para: Edubuntu &distro-rev; supports three (3) major architectures: Intel x86, AMD64, and PowerPC. Depending on your needs, you might manage with less than some of the recommended hardware listed in the table below. However, most users risk being frustrated if they ignore these suggestions.

Here are some common Edubuntu &distro-rev; system configurations. Once again, the size of the installation will greatly depend on the software you install during setup. For most users, the default applications are suitable for general use.

listitem.para: A standard desktop machine, including the X window system, full desktop environment, sound, office suite, email clients, etc. You'll need about 2 gigabytes of hard drive space using the standard desktop task.

This is a small server profile, which provides a common base for all sorts of server applications. It's minimal and designed to have the desired services added on top, such as file/print services, web hosting, email hosting, etc. For these services as little as 500MB of disk space would suffice, but consider adding more space depending on the services you'd like to host with your server.

sect2.para: Remember that these sizes don't include all the other materials which are usually to be found, such as user files, mail, and data. It is always best to be generous when considering the space for your own files and data.

sect2.title: Installing EdEdubuntu &distro-rev;
sect2.para: Once you have a copy of Edubuntu &distro-rev;, follow these instructions to install:

sect3.title: Default Mode
sect3.para: The default installation mode provides the best computing experience with Edubuntu &distro-rev;. You'll have a fully functioning desktop with the default settings. Make sure your computer meets the recommended minimum requirements when installing in Default Mode.

listitem.para: Place the Edubuntu &distro-rev; Install CD in the CD-ROM Drive and power on the computer.
At boot:, press Enter.
The Edubuntu &distro-rev; installer will run. Follow the on-screen instructions to start the installation.
Once the installation is complete, the login screen will appear and you are ready to use Edubuntu &distro-rev;

sect3.title: Server Mode
sect3.para: The Server Mode provides a base system suitable for installing server applications. You can add more services as needed after installation. Make sure your computer meets the recommended minimum specifications when installing in Default Mode.

listitem.para: Place the Edubuntu &distro-rev; Install CD in the CD-ROM Drive and power on the computer.
At boot:, type server, and press Enter.
The Edubuntu &distro-rev; installer will run. Follow the on-screen instructions to start the installation.
Once the installation is complete, you will be informed that your Edubuntu &distro-rev; is ready for use.

sect3.title: OEM Mode
sect3.para: Edubuntu &distro-rev; can be pre-installed to computers for resale and redistribution. Make sure the computer meets the recommended minimum specifications when installing in OEM Mode.

listitem.para: Place the Edubuntu &distro-rev; Install CD in the CD-ROM Drive and power on the computer.
At boot:, type oem and press Enter.
The Edubuntu &distro-rev; installer will run. Follow the on-screen instructions to start the installation.
Once the installation is complete, you will be informed that Edubuntu &distro-rev; has been fully installed and the computer is ready for shipping.

You can also run a system test to check if the installation of Edubuntu &distro-rev; OEM mode went smoothly. The system test will run the Edubuntu Hardware Database and will check that your hardware is configured correctly.

On the first boot after installation, you will be asked to select your language, keyboard layout, and time zone configuration, and create your first user account. The first user account created has administrative rights via sudo. Since Edubuntu &distro-rev; is a multi-user system, you can create more user accounts as needed.

note.para: You can read more in-depth FAQs in the Edubuntu &distro-rev; FAQ Guide .

sect1.title: Getting Help and Technical Support
sect1.para:
Edubuntu &distro-rev; gives users an easy way to get help in most applications installed by default. Once you have an active Internet connection, from an open application, just click on
Help Get Help Online
and you'll be connected to a web page that gives you help and support options for the application.

Technical Support for Edubuntu &distro-rev; is available from a variety of sources: from the community, from Canonical Ltd, from recognized organizations, and from developers directly through open web forums, mailing lists, and IRC channels:
